column4: hey I think my connection went sour because I stopped seeing any chat for the last 5+ minutes... anyway I typed the command in the terminal and I see the drives and the partitions /sda1 /sdb1
I did
and what's new when you type "ls /dev/sd*" ?
/dev/sda  /dev/sda1  /dev/sdb  /dev/sdb1
and neither of those were present when the drive was unplugged?
i think at least /dev/sda1 was ...
sdb is the 2nd hd that has my backup   sdb was not present when it was unplugged
i thought you said that drive had 2 partitons on it ....
gparted made it look that way but it does not. basically I want to mount both drives and then run the dd command to restore the backup on sdb1 to sda1
lemme try
how is /dev/sdb1 formatted?
both drives are ntfs
when I unplug sda sdb does not change to sda
sudo mkdir /media/backup-drive && sudo mount -t ntfs /dev/sdb1 /media/backup-drive
okay that worked without error and I can now browse the files in file browser
great
so now I'm gonna perform the same command for the other drive
you'll need a different mount point
great I can browse both thanks a lot. I also just finally learned that the number after the drive represents partitions I was always confused about what sda and sda were
sudo mkdir /media/ye-olde-other-drive && sudo mount -t ntfs /dev/sdb1 /media/ye-olde-other-drive
sudo mkdir /media/ye-olde-other-drive && sudo mount -t ntfs /dev/sda1 /media/ye-olde-other-drive
yeah it's all good I already mounted it
you too :)
